Fields.DialogueText: So, what are you working on?
I'm taking some field notes on the marine life in the area. Do you see those dolphins?

Fields.MenuText: Of course! Did you know that dolphins are a sign of good luck?
What do you notice about them?
Yeah. Wait... that species of dolphin isn't native to this region, is it?

Fields.DialogueText: Until now, I never took you for being such a superstitious old sailor.
Very good, Kapitän! But that's not the only thing about them that is unusual.
Their behavior has been very strange.
Strange?
Ja. They seem agitated, in some way.
Perhaps the Morganas have been bothering them.
*ALARM*
Hm, well, I'm sure the Morganas haven't helped them.
@BATTLE
Hello, Twenty-nine. Feeling better?
Ja. I'm still reflecting on what I experienced, but I've certainly recovered from it.
You've been very kind to me, you know.

Fields.MenuText: I'm kind to everybody. I'm famous for it!
Actually, I think I've been in your way and you're too polite to say.
You must be imagining things.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Of course.
I'm not often accused of being too polite. And it's possible I need someone in my way every now and then.
Ah. Of course.
Looks like you'll have to put a hold on your field notes. We've got some new orders.
Ja? Tell me more.
It seems there've been a number of disappearances in the area. Cargo ships, mostly, but a few warships, too. We've been ordered to get to the bottom of this.
That should be easy, since I'm a submarine.

Fields.MenuText: Let's hope so.
You're always brimming with confidence, U-29
I didn't mean it literally.

Fields.DialogueText: Since when have we had a hard time with anything?
Why shouldn't I be confident?
Maybe not, but it still might be interpreted that way.
You're incorrigible.
I don't know what you mean, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
Morganas ahead! Everyone to your stations!
Ah, could this be our first lead?
@BATTLE
Have you ever thought about the pattern in which we encounter Morganas?
I'm not sure what you mean by that.
@BATTLE
Well, they always appear in small groups, and spread out over time. We hardly ever find a genuine armada of them.

Fields.MenuText: Huh, I guess I noticed that. I figured it was just part of their disorganization.
I think a big part of it is that they're competing for resources. They don't seem very inclined to share.
Do you have a theory about this?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps - but it never hurts to think about these things.
Agreed. Hmm...
I have a few, actually.
I have no doubt you'll have it solved in no time.
Unfortunately, I don't have time to think about this right now, Kapitän. Remember, we are on a mission.
As if you're only thinking about one thing at a time.
You can't blame me if I have a superior investigative sense. It's my German heritage.
Hopefully, when we get to Bremerhaven, you will figure out why ships are disappearing.
Luckily, I won't have to figure it out by myself.
Kapitän?
I see them.
Captain! You should probably come up and see this!
... Huh.
An enormous flock of seagulls! How strange.
Never in my life have I seen so many birds at a single location.
I don't think I've ever seen or heard of anything like this, Kapitän.
They're blotting out the sun...
Don't tell me you're going to start being superstitious about this.
Uh, no, ma'am.
Let's get back inside, U-29 - I can barely hear you.
Hmm... Did those birds seem to you like they were doing anything in particular, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Um, besides forming into a massive mega-flock?
You have a theory. Out with it.
No, but I'm guessing they did to you.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, yes, naturally.
You're no fun, Kapitän.
I'll make an investigator of you yet.
*ALARM*
Never mind the birds. We've got Morganas closing in.
@BATTLE
You look excited today, U-29.
That's because I am, Kapitän. You see, Bremen is my hometown, and I haven't been there since I was built.
Is that so?
@BATTLE
Ja. I'd offer to show you around, but...

Fields.MenuText: I'd settle for a really thorough tour of the docks.
You can't walk more than 30 feet from the ship.
It's quite all right, U-29 I'm not sure that we have time for that sort of thing, anyway.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! That, I might be able to provide.
Ja. I guess it doesn't matter, because I couldn't walk around when I was here last time, either.
Ah, I suppose you're right.
It makes you think.
Oh? About what?
Beginnings, I suppose. The past.
Hmm, now I'm imagining you as a young, fresh-faced cadet at the naval academy, Kapitän.
Is that so?
Ja. I'm imagining you as being quite the adventurous figure.
Now, I am imagining your hazing when you were a first-year cadet. I picture you... having to wear a beanie all the time. Ja.
Oh look, we're here!
Ready, Twenty-Nine? They're almost in range...
More than ready. The sooner this is done, the sooner we can move forward.

Fields.MenuText: I should hope so. I was top of my class.
That's what I said every time they threatened to expel me!
I hate to break it to you, but I've never been to a naval academy.

Fields.DialogueText: A career of scandal? Tell me more.
Oh! So now I have a much more interesting career to speculate about, don't I? Let's see - what would you have done before the war?
How does Bremerhaven compare to your memory?
It's not much different. Truth be told, I didn't leave that long ago. Still... people look tired. Worn out.

Fields.MenuText: Do you not remember them being that way before?
This is a major shipping center. I expect people are very busy.
Who isn't tired these days?

Fields.DialogueText: Not as bad, at least.
True, but I think there is more to it than just that.
That's true enough. Why are you people so tired all the time?
Well, there is a war going on. Two wars, actually.
Both of which, I am sure, we are quite capable of winning with men and women such as yourselves in uniform.
Ah, you must be Mr. Schweiss. I'm sure you'll recognize U-29; I have the honor of being her captain.
Delighted.
Our orders instructed us to meet you and ask if you had any information for us regarding these disappearances.
Ah, straight to business. I like that. Very well-done. As you know, I have been sent here as a representative of the Senat der Hansestadt Bremen.
Beginning several weeks ago, out in the Baltic, ships starting disappearing. At first, we thought it was the Morganas, or even the British, breaking the truce.
And now what do you think is causing them?
To be honest, we have no idea. Only that the escorts have been disappearing, too, and no Morgana has managed to sink ships, merchant or military, with this efficiency.
*ALARM*
Ah, speaking of which. They regularly like to test our defenses. It's a simple enough matter to defend the docks, but I suppose you'll want to assist, anyway.
@BATTLE
Well done there! Now, where are we?
You were telling us your suspicions about the disappearances.
Ah, right, of course. Unfortunately, I don't have a lot more to say. It is all so mysterious.
Can you tell us anything about the ships that disappeared? What they were carrying, where were they going?
Oh, yes, of course. I brought along everything we know. Cargo manifests, ship schematics, travel schedules, etc. It's all in this brief case I have here for you.
Danke, Mr. Schweiss. If we have any more questions, we will contact you.
Of course. Good day, U-29. Good day, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Well, he didn't seem to know much.
What did he say he did, again?
Does it look like there's much useful in that briefcase, U-29?

Fields.DialogueText: Nein - but let's hope these documents are helpful.
I believe he represented the "Senat der Hansestadt Bremen." I suspect it was purposefully broad.
It's hard to know, Kapitän, but there could be. There's certainly enough material in here.
Well, let's get going, then.
*ALARM*
Are you kidding? We just left the port, and they're already on us...
@BATTLE
So... they are definitely Morganas, right? What else could be sinking these ships?
What else, indeed.
You saw how aggressive they have been. They skirmish around Bremerhaven all the time, and they were waiting for us when we left the port.
Das ist richtig. And, ja, I suppose Morganas are the most likely suspect.
But?
I don't know. Something just feels off.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't seem very rational.
What are you thinking?
If they are not Morganas, then what are they?

Fields.DialogueText: Intuition is not the same thing as superstition, Kapitän.
That Morganas most likely have been sinking these ships. It is the most plausible explanation.
That's quite the question, isn't it?
*ALARM*
There they are now. Perhaps we can ask them?
@BATTLE
Have you taken a look at those documents Mr. Schweiss gave us?
Just briefly. There is a lot of material there, but nothing has caught my attention yet.
@BATTLE
Lt. Kurtz?
Yes, Kapitän?
Contact all our observation posts in the area. See if you can find any information on Morgana movements in the Baltic Sea over the last two weeks.
Yes, Kapitän.
Sehr gut! If we collect data on the locations of Morganas in the region, we will be able to cross-reference the data with the schedules of these disappearing ships and see if they match.

Fields.MenuText: I have my moments.
You sound almost surprised, U-29
Oh, had you not thought of that?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't doubt you do.
Oh, I do? I suppose that I'm just surprised that I have managed to rub off on you so much.
Uh, well, I have been very busy lately, going through those documents.
The sea is so fascinating. Sometimes, I wish this war were over so I could dedicate all of my time to studying it.
Really? I figured you'd want to dedicate your time to reading mystery novels.
One can only spend so much time reading, Kapitän. And they're more accurately classified as pulp novels.
Correction noted - but my point still stands. Though I could also see you dedicating time to studying the occult.
Well, that's really more of a hobby than anything else.
Or maybe teaching naval tactics.
Oh, look at that bird. Can you identify it, Kapitän?
Too far out for human eyes, I'm afraid. What is it?
That's an albatross. Albatrosses are quite interesting. They fly thousands of miles across the world's oceans, all by themselves.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds lonely.
You're right. You should study the sea.
It's amazing what a single, solitary bird can do.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, ja. I guess it does, doesn't it?
Do you really think so?
Ja, it is.
We have Morganas incoming, Captain!
*ALARM*
Ah, well... we can't sightsee all day, anyway.
@BATTLE
It's a fine day - don't you think so, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Absolutely.
What has you in such a good mood?
What are you up to?

Fields.DialogueText: It's just a fine day for a mystery.
It's obvious... I smell a mystery, Kapitän!
I'm just taking a break from looking through those files and smelling the salt air!
Kapitän! Kapitän!
What is it?
We've just picked up a distress call from a transport ship under attack!
Did they give their location?
Yes, Kapitän.
Then let's go!
Morganas are coming in!
*ALARM*
Damn. We don't have time for this.
@BATTLE
We're at the location the distress call gave. I don't see a ship. Do you?
Ja. You can just see what's left of it over there if you squint, I think.
Lieutenant, I want a search for survivors. Immediately.
Yes, Kapitän.
Do you think it was a coincidence that Morganas slowed us down like that?
It's hard to say. I want to say they're connected, but we get attacked by Morganas so damn often. It could just be a coincidence.
I don't believe in coincidences, Kapitän.
That, U-29, I believe.
What's that supposed to mean?
... Ja. That's fair.
Of course not, Kapitän. I was just trying to be sarcastic.
I think, Kapitän, that means that you know me very well.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
We couldn't find anyone, Kapitän.
Damn. I wouldn't expect swimmers to last in these waters, but I'd hoped a lifeboat or two might....
I'm sorry - I was unclear. We couldn't find anybody: no survivors, and no bodies.
... Damn.

Fields.MenuText: Only that you're always searching for a mystery.
Uh - did I upset you?
What do you think that means?

Fields.DialogueText: Let's go down and examine the wreckage, then.
Preparing to submerge!

Fields.MenuText: What do you expect to find?
I don't think there will be much left.
Hey, wait, I didn't give the order to dive yet!

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing specifically, but gathering as much evidence as possible should be a high priority for us right now.
True, but you would be surprised by how much information can be gleaned from a small sample.
You've got to keep up, Kapitän.
We're approaching the wreckage now. Twenty-nine, are you willing to do a bit of swimming?
Natürlich... oh! What was that?!
Something collided with us!
There's something out there! There's something in the water!
Twenty-nine! Any idea what we're dealing with?
I can just barely perceive a shape out in there... It's coming back around!
Brace for impact!
Uh!
Damn... Take us back up.
Ahh...
Oh.
Whoa...
I think it's gone.
Morganas are on the radar!
Yeah, there's a shock.
@BATTLE
Do me a favor and look abashed so the crew thinks I'm chewing you out.
This *is* my abashed face.
Yeah, fair enough.
Well, it took a long time to get the lights working. But at least I completed my examination of the sunken cargo ship.
And?
I don't think you're going to like this.
I suspect you're probably right about that.
Whatever sunk that ship... it wasn't Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Ah, hell. Pirates?
Really? Go on.
Just as I thought.

Fields.DialogueText: Unlikely. Please just give me a minute to explain.
Sehr gut.
Oh? You are full of surprises.
The ship sank due to massive rump deformation.
However, due to the patterning on breaches, you can tell it wasn't done by cannon or torpedo.
Not only was it not sunk by Morganas - at least not Morganas using conventional weapons - it may not have even been another ship.
I don't like this.
I told you you wouldn't, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Well, Twenty-Nine, we've been patrolling for a few days now, and nothing has happened. Well, except for skirmishes with Morganas.
The patient detective only has to wait.
Well, does the patient detective have any theories while she waits?
Ha. Well, no concrete theories. The most plausible theory I have right now is that it is some species of highly aggressive whale.

Fields.MenuText: Whale?
A whale like Moby Dick?
It would have to be an undiscovered species to sink a modern naval vessel, wouldn't it? I can't imagine any beast known to science doing that kind of damage.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja.
Ja. In fact, we may find it's very much like Moby Dick.
Hmm. Maybe, Kapitän, but even then, the sea is vast and deep. I would be surprised if there were not any unknown species of whale.
I believe a large enough specimen could ram the side of a ship, causing the damage we saw.
I... suppose that makes as much sense as anything else. But, then, why are there attacks by whales?
That's where I am less confident. I went back and looked through the various ships' cargo manifests, to see if there was anything in common.
Anything that might have agitated a whale in some way. I couldn't find anything.
So where does that leave us? A rogue whale with no clear motive?
It appears so, Kapitän.
Sure.
Well, it turns out they actually did remind me of something. I've read about similar behavior before, but it's rare, rare enough that I didn't immediately make the connection.
Yes?
They were running away, Kapitän.
Kapitän, they're almost in range.
Right. Everyone brace yourselves for the inevitable pre-battle gibberish.
@BATTLE
Wait, I just remembered something. Do you remember those seagulls we saw flying in that huge flock?
Kapitän, we've just picked up an SOS on the radio. We have their coordinates.
Set a course. Can you hail them?
We're trying, Kapitän.
... This is the SS Edelweiss. Hello?
Hello! Can you hear us? This is the Kriegsmarine vessel U-29.
Thank God!
We are on our way to get you... what's wrong?
We don't know. We're being followed by... something. It- *static*
I'm sorry, I didn't hear you. Can you repeat that?
...dead. Oh, God. We're being followed by... something. We're not sure... Oh!
*Static*
...Damn.
Let's go check it out.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think we'll find?
Make sure we have a harpoon ready, okay?
Well, patient detective, you have your next lead.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure anymore.
Torpedoes might be preferable, even though they are non-traditional.
Ah, I told you!
Kapitän, we've been spotted.
Right. Let's do this quickly; I think we have more pressing business out here.
@BATTLE
Nothing but flotsam. Just like last time.
Wait! Kapitän, do you see that?
A lifeboat! Lieutenant, recover that boat.
On it, Kapitän.
This could be a major breakthrough in our investigation.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, you think so?
Yes, it's quite exciting!
Let's not get ahead of ourselves.

Fields.DialogueText: No need to be snarky, Kapitän.
Yes, so let's hurry up and gather in the lifeboat. I have so many questions!
Oh, don't be such a spoilsport.
*ALARM*
Dammit! Get us between the Morganas and that lifeboat!
@BATTLE
The lifeboat is aboard, Kapitän. One survivor. He doesn't seem to have any life-threatening injuries.
Very good. Is he in any condition to talk to us?
Ah. I'm... not sure.
What does that mean?
I think you'll have to see for yourself.
Well, let's go, then.
He is called Leviathan, the piercing serpent. Leviathan, the crooked serpent. Leviathan, the dragon of the sea.
He's been like this since we found him.
Hallo? Can you tell us your name?
In his wake swirls the fate of kingdoms. Death clings to him like sea foam. He is called Leviathan.
Can you tell us what happened?
No. No. No. Not yet. No. His breath moves legions in the deep. No.
Hm. Any thoughts?
Two. First, this man needs sustained psychological care. Second, we're looking for a monster of a whale.
So, can we talk?
Oh! Um, ja. Of course we can talk.
Did you get anything out of the survivor?
Ah! I see!
Wait, what did you think I wanted to talk about?
Nothing, it doesn't matter. Anyway. Nein, I couldn't get anything rational out of him. Just babbling.
You're probably not going to like hearing me say this, but something seems strange about all of this.
Strange?
We have seen fleeing hordes of seagulls, ships attacked by some sort of whale, sailors babbling insanely... it all just seems so... portentous.
Now, Kapitän, don't tell me you're getting all superstitious about this.

Fields.MenuText: After the things I've seen, I don't feel like it's fair to call it superstition anymore.

Fields.DialogueText: So what would you suggest? That we are both superstitious?
*ALARM*
We'll talk later.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I am. Maybe you should be, too.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein. I admit, something strange is going on, but at least one of us needs to keep a rational head.

Fields.MenuText: There's nothing superstitious about recognizing what's happening and trying to find a pattern.

Fields.DialogueText: I can agree with you there.
Ready for another round, Twenty-Nine?
Ja. Always.
@BATTLE
What? Is that music?
It is, though I couldn't tell you exactly what. It's Lieutenant Kurtz's record.
It's nice.
You know it's dance music, though, right?
Oh. Well, I don't know how to dance.

Fields.MenuText: You don't know how to dance? That needs remedying this minute!

Fields.DialogueText: Well, if you're giving me an order, who am I to disobey?
For the purposes of demonstration, I'll take the lead.
That seems only fair.
Okay, put your hand here, and move your feet like this. Hey! You've got it.
You're actually pretty good at this, Kapitän!
You sound so surprised! Dancing is part of an officer's education.
I kind of doubt that, Kapitän.
Well, okay, maybe not officially. But it beats ascribing it all to a wayward youth.
However you learned, I'd say that it paid off for you.
I'm going to spin you. Are you ready?
Whoah! Ha ha!
You've got it!

Fields.MenuText: I could teach you.

Fields.DialogueText: If you insist, Kapitän.
I think I might have a lead, Kapitän.
On our Leviathan? Excellent.
Bear in mind, however, the source is a bit... tenuous.
Okay?
Using what little information I could glean from the survivor's ramblings, I searched through my texts to see if I could find any matches.
I think I may have found one. The pagan Prussians had a legend concerning a great sea monster. Its name is literally translated as "The Terror of the Sea."
It was said it could swallow whole ships in one bite. The destruction of at least one coastal city by an earthquake was blamed on the sea monster. I could go on, but I think you get the idea.
Do you have any information that we can make good use of?
Not much, I'm afraid. Physical descriptions of the creature vary wildly, often trending toward the fanciful.
However, one story claims the beast lives underneath the island of Blå in the Baltic Sea.
Great! Let's head there and check it out.
Of course, I doubt it's one beast. More likely, a species of whale lives around that island, and is large enough to have captured the imagination of this ancient people.

Fields.MenuText: Let's hope it's just that.

Fields.DialogueText: Let's do more than just hope, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
Let's deal with these Morganas, first.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: So do you still think it's just a whale?

Fields.DialogueText: What else could it possibly be?
All right. We're on our way to Blå, and we should get there in a few days.
Sehr gut. That will give us time to prepare.
What is there to prepare for? Isn't this just a large whale?
About that...

Fields.MenuText: Don't tell me you've embraced superstition, U-29.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not. I've just re-evaluated my stance after discovering new evidence.
So what's changed?
After examining the Prussian sources, I noticed something I couldn't ignore. In some of the stories, signs are given of the creature's passing. These include frightened wildlife.
Like those seagulls we saw.
Indeed. Most concerning of all, though, are the stories that say the creature's presence is accompanied by a... strangeness in the stars.
Wait, like when you said you thought some constellations were off. So, is this is some kind of scary whale that's into astrology?
I... don't know, Kapitän. I want to be rational about this, but this seems too big to ignore. I just don't know.
It's okay, Twenty-Nine. We'll figure this out. Together.
Ja. I know.
Morganas approaching, Captain!
I wonder if they're having trouble with this creature, too?
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What are you thinking about now?

Fields.DialogueText: That we might be dealing with something other than just a whale.

Fields.MenuText: I hate it when you say that.

Fields.DialogueText: Look, it's not my fault we keep encountering strange things!
Here are the reports, Kapitän.
Thank you, Lieutenant.
Anything?
No sign of this creature. But if we posit that its nesting ground is some kind of undersea cave...
Ja. We need to draw it out, then.
So, next question. How do we do that?
Fire some torpedoes at it? I'm not sure. Honestly, I'm surprised we haven't attracted its attention yet.
Torpedoes could work.
Ah, I'm not sure that's really a good idea. I was just joking. This creature is likely incredibly rare, maybe even unique to this island.
Our orders are to deal with it. If it's sinking ships, we have to kill it. I'm sorry, but a lot of people are dying.
I suppose you're right, Kapitän. Still, if we could capture it somehow...
*ALARM*
Hmm. Are they following us?
@BATTLE
Morganas are almost in range. And you look... surprisingly excited.
This could work in our favor - if the noise of battle rouses the creature, and brings it out to us....
One nightmarish encounter at a time, please.
@BATTLE
Here's the plan: once the creature comes out to feed, we'll catch it in this net I've prepared.
Net? Where did you get the net?
Kapitän, I've been talking to fishermen since we got here. I bought every fishing net in the area.
Okay. What if the net doesn't work?
Then we have to fall back on Plan B: torpedoes.
Sounds like a good plan.
I'm picking something up, Kapitän! I think we have our Leviathan.
Here we go.
And a kiss for good luck.
Hehe.
We have a visual, Kapitän.
Here it comes. Get ready!
My God.
That's not a whale.
Oh. No. No, it is not.
I don't think a net's going to work.
Let's skip to Plan C.
Fire everything we've got!

Fields.MenuText: Hm. I'm not sure I got enough good luck.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, you can wait until after we fight the sea monster.

Fields.MenuText: You always did favor a bold plan of attack, Twenty-Nine.

Fields.DialogueText: All is fair in love and war, Kapitän. Especially when they're the same.
I can't believe we did it.
I think there's enough left for me to perform a necropsy.
That's gross. Now, kiss me.
Nein. Focus. We just killed an ancient sea monster that's been plaguing this region, however erratically, for centuries. Does that mean we accomplished the mission?
I dare say it does, Twenty-Nine.
Enough to warrant a vacation, perhaps?
What about your necropsy?
What part of "ancient sea monster necropsy" seems incongruous with a vacation to you?

Fields.MenuText: Ha! We do make a great team, though, don't we?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. We really do. Now... I want to kiss you.
*ALARM*
It is obviously time for a break.
Yes, a break doesn't sound too bad. Maybe we could look at the stars together.
Sigh.
Captain to the bridge!
Well, duty calls, Kapitän.
That it does, U-29. Let's go win a war.

Fields.MenuText: Okay, now that is gross.

Fields.DialogueText: I think we can agree that it is all gross.

Fields.MenuText: You're amazing.

Fields.DialogueText: You are amazing too, Kapitän.
Oh, good evening, Twenty-Nine.
Hmm... ten degrees... quadrant... oh! Hello, Kapitän.
What are you up to?
Well...
Yes?
I'm afraid it sounds rather silly.

Fields.MenuText: You? Silly? I can't imagine.

Fields.DialogueText: You would be surprised. I'm a little surprised myself, to tell the truth.
I'm double-checking the stars.
What?
I told you that it was silly. I keep re-checking, and each time I do that, a few constellations are out of alignment. I don't know what to make of it.
Well, it is still a beautiful night, even if the stars are wrong.
You're not looking at the sky when you say that.
I know.
Kapitän!
What. Is. It. Lieutenant?
We have Morganas coming in!
Ah, duty calls.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I could use a little silliness right now.

Fields.DialogueText: In that case, I'll tell you.

Fields.MenuText: I promise I won't tell.

Fields.DialogueText: Sehr gut. A girl has to keep her reputation, after all.
